question: A queue follows the First In, First Out (FIFO) principle.
In a queue, the last element added is the first one to be removed.
Job scheduling in an operating system makes use of a queue.
In Round Robin scheduling, a queue is not required.
A printer queue processes documents in the order they were sent.
Keystrokes on a keyboard are processed using a stack data structure.
Mouse movement data is stored in a queue before being processed by the system.
Customer service call centers use queues to manage waiting calls.
A stack is the preferred data structure for handling multiple users accessing a website at the same time.
Routers and switches use queues to store and process data packets sequentially.
Cloud computing platforms do not use queues for resource management.
A queue is used in ticket booking systems to process seat reservations.
When booking tickets online, user requests are processed in a random order.
Online order processing in e-commerce follows a queue system.
At a fast-food restaurant, customers are served randomly rather than in the order they arrived.
Queues help manage multiple downloads in web browsers efficiently.
In networking, data packets are processed using a Last In, First Out (LIFO) approach.
Multithreading applications use queues to schedule tasks efficiently.
Queues are useful in system design, networking, and resource management.
A queue is an unordered data structure that does not follow any sequence for processing elements.
